resource.chars:
The <u>second</u> period commences with the presentation <s>of</s> to the
Académie des Sciences, of M. D'Orbigny "Tableau Méthodique
de la Classe des Cephalopodes",in which he first separated
these chambered shells,under the title of <u>Foraminifera</u>, from the
<u>Siphonifera</u>; still retaining the former, however, like the latter,
as an order of Cephalopods. A large number of new forms were
added by M.D'Orbigny to the list of those previously known;
and he <s>then</s> laid the basis of the classification which he
has since more fully elaborated. No suspicion appears
then to have crossed his mind, that the place of these bodies
might be amongst the lowest, instead of among the higher
of the Invertebrata; and if his determination of their molluscous
nature was based on any actual observations of these animals
in their living state, it is certain that such observations must
have been of the most superficial character. 

The third period, with which our knowledge of the true
nature of the Foraminifera really commenced, is, inaugurated
by the discovery, first announced by M Dujardin to the
Académie des Sciences in June 1835, of the <s>Rhizopodous</s> nature of
